issues.description: The problem statement and the template expect a no-argument Rideable.messageOnRide() that returns a String (the instructions and the commented Main call r.messageOnRide() with no parameters). However, the solution implements Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) (and Pig/Seal implement messageOnRide(int speed)). This is an API parameter mismatch: the solution's ride method requires an int parameter while the specification and template expect no parameters. Additionally, the solution's own Main (commented usage) calls messageOnRide() with no argument, creating a self-contradiction inside the solution artifact. This mismatch will confuse students about the correct method signature and will prevent code/examples/tests that assume the no-arg signature from compiling against the provided solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Rideable API across artifacts. Either (A) change the solution to match the problem/template by declaring Rideable.messageOnRide() with no parameters and update Pig and Seal to implement a no-arg messageOnRide() returning "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]", or (B) update the problem statement and template (and any tests/Main) to document/use the int speed parameter if that behavior (speed-aware riding) is intended. Option (A) is recommended because the problem text, UML, and template Main explicitly expect a no-argument method.

issues.description: The problem specification and UML define Rideable.messageOnRide() as a no-argument method returning a String (and Part 2 explicitly says messageOnRide() should return "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]"). The template/main code (commented examples) also call messageOnRide() with no arguments. However, the solution repository defines Rideable.messageOnRide(int speed) (adds an int parameter) and implements it in Pig and Seal returning strings that include speed ("... at X mph"). This mismatches the problem/template contract (name/signature and expected return), creating a mapping confusion for students: they will expect a no-arg messageOnRide() per the exercise but find a parameterized version in the reference solution and implementations.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method signature and behavior across artifacts. Either: (A) Update the solution to match the problem/template by changing Rideable.messageOnRide(int) to messageOnRide() and modify Pig/Seal implementations to return "Riding on [Animal Type] [name]" (no speed); or (B) If the speed parameter is intended, update the problem statement and template examples (UML and Part 2 wording) to declare messageOnRide(int speed) and adjust the expected return string to include the speed. Option A is recommended to preserve the original exercise specification.
